content: The Act titled "Small Business and Financial Institutions Tax Relief Act of 2001" allows IRAs to be eligible shareholders of S Corporation banks. The "Small Business and Financial Institutions Tax Relief Act of 2001" permits IRAs to be shareholders of S Corporation banks, with specific conditions regarding stock holdings. The "Small Business and Financial Institutions Tax Relief Act of 2001" allows IRAs to own stock in S Corporation banks, with conditions. Trusts described in clause (vi) of subparagraph (A) treat the beneficiary as a shareholder. Section 4975(d) of the Internal Revenue Code exempts the sale of stock held by an IRA to the beneficiary if sold under section 1362(a). The amendments made by this section apply to taxable years beginning after December 31, 2001. SEC. 3. Excludes investment securities income from passive income test for bank S corporations. The amendment excludes certain types of income from the passive investment income definition for banks and bank holding companies under the Internal Revenue Code. The amendment excludes specific types of income from passive investment income definition for banks, bank holding companies, or qualified subchapter S subsidiary banks to conduct banking business. Effective date: applicable to taxable years starting after December 31, 1996. SEC. 4. INCREASE IN NUMBER OF ELIGIBLE SHAREHOLDERS TO 150. Amends the Internal Revenue Code to increase the number of eligible shareholders for small business corporations to 150. Effective for taxable years starting after December 31, 2001. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to include a provision regarding the treatment of qualifying director shares in banks or bank holding companies. Qualifying director shares are not considered a second class of stock, and holding them does not make an individual a shareholder of the corporation. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to include a provision regarding the treatment of qualifying director shares in banks or bank holding companies. Qualifying director shares are not considered a second class of stock, and holding them does not make an individual a shareholder of the corporation. Distributions made by the corporation with respect to qualifying director shares shall be includible as ordinary income of the holder and deductible to the corporation as an expense. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to include provisions for qualifying director shares in banks or bank holding companies. These shares are not considered a second class of stock, and holders are not considered shareholders of the corporation. Distributions with respect to qualifying director shares are included as ordinary income for the holder and deductible as an expense for the corporation. Amendments are made to sections 1361, 1366, and 1373 of the Code. The amendments made by this section state that no deductible expenses under this subchapter can be allocated to certain income. These changes will apply to taxable years starting after December 31, 1996. SEC. 6. The Treasury Secretary will adjust regulations for S corporation elections after December 31, 1996, regarding bad debt deductions to be treated as built-in losses during the period of recognizing built-in gains. SEC. 7. Banks will be included in the 3-year S corporation rule for corporate preference items. SEC. 8 expands S corporation eligible shareholders to include family limited partnerships, effective for taxable years starting after December 31, 2001. SEC. 8 expands S corporation eligible shareholders to include family limited partnerships, effective for taxable years starting after December 31, 2001. The amendment allows family partnerships to be shareholders in an S corporation if all partners or members are members of one family as determined under section 704(e)(3). The amendments made by section 8 expand S corporation eligible shareholders to include family partnerships where all partners or members are part of the same family as defined in section 704(e)(3). Each partner or member in the partnership or limited liability company described in the amendment shall be treated as a shareholder for tax purposes. The effective date for these changes is for taxable years beginning after December 31, 2001. SEC. 9. ISSUANCE OF PREFERRED STOCK PERMITTED. The amendment allows qualified preferred stock to not be treated as a second class of stock and shareholders holding such stock are not considered shareholders of the corporation. Qualified preferred stock is defined as stock meeting specific requirements outlined in the code. The amendment allows distributions made by the corporation with respect to qualified preferred stock to be included as ordinary income for the holder and deductible as an expense for the corporation. Conforming amendments are made to sections of the Internal Revenue Code to accommodate qualified preferred stock. The holders of qualified preferred stock are not allocated certain items. Section 1373(a)(3) is amended to include references to section 1361(g)(3). These amendments apply to taxable years starting after December 31, 2001. SEC. 10. CONSENT TO ELECTIONS. Section 1362(a)(2) of the Internal Revenue Code is amended to require consent from shareholders holding at least 90 percent of shares for an election. Rules for consent include joint owners and personal representatives consenting for their shares. The consent requirements for different types of shareholders include the personal representative for deceased individuals, parents or guardians for minors, trustees for trusts, and authorized officers for organizations. In the case of partnerships or limited liability companies, all general partners, managers, or members must consent to the shares owned by the organization. This is in accordance with Section 1361 of the Internal Revenue Code. Nonconsenting shareholder stock in an S corporation is not considered a second class of stock, but rather C corporation stock. The shareholder's pro rata share with respect to this stock is subject to tax at the highest rate specified in the Internal Revenue Code. Nonconsenting shareholder stock in an S corporation is treated as C corporation stock. Distributions made with respect to this stock are taxable as ordinary income to the holder and deductible to the corporation. Amendments to the Internal Revenue Code include adding subsection (h) to section 1361(b)(1). The amendments made by this section apply to elections in taxable years starting after December 31, 2001. SEC. 11 amends the Internal Revenue Code regarding information returns for qualified Subchapter S subsidiaries. SEC. 12 allows charitable contributions of inventory and scientific property. The amendments apply to taxable years starting after December 31, 2001. The Internal Revenue Code is amended to adjust basis of stock for charitable contributions exceeding property basis. The Internal Revenue Code is amended to adjust basis of stock for charitable contributions exceeding property basis, effective for taxable years beginning after December 31, 2001.
